summary: Artichoke is green, earthy, and faintly bitter from sesquiterpene lactones, while cynarin enhances perceived sweetness. Gentle heat preserves herbal freshness; roasting/grilling adds toasted and nutty depth. Acid and fat temper bitterness and highlight sweetness.
additional_notes: Cynarin can make water taste sweet after eating artichoke.
Seasonality: peak spring; available year-round in some regions.
Techniques: steam, braise, roast, grill, confit; trim fibrous choke.
Bitterness is balanced by salt and acid; fat amplifies savory depth.

matrix_nodes.label: Earthy
matrix_nodes.notes: Mineral depth; aligns with mushroom, potato

uncertainties: Exact wheel percentages unreadable on photo; sizes normalized 0–1 by visual proportion and reference.
Minor floral/fruit sublabels not fully legible; inferred from book taxonomy.

summary: Beef ranges from metallic-lean to deeply meaty depending on cut, fat, and aging. Maillard browning drives roasted, nutty, and toasted aromas; marrow and dry-aging boost umami and funk. Herbs, alliums, and acids cut richness; mushrooms and coffee amplify savory depth.
additional_notes: Dry-aging increases nutty, blue-cheese-like notes (proteolysis, lipolysis).
Searing creates pyrazines and thiophenes characteristic of grilled beef.
Acids (wine, vinegar) and mustard brighten and tenderize.

matrix_nodes.label: Fruity/Acidic
matrix_nodes.notes: Red wine, berry sauces cut fat

uncertainties: Outer ring sublabels (specific spices, herbs) vary by cut/prep; normalized from reference.
Relative sizes normalized 0–1 based on typical matrix for beef.

summary: Beets are earthy and sweet from geosmin and sugars. Roasting intensifies caramel and nutty notes; pickling emphasizes acidity; raw beet shows green, floral top notes. Pair well with dairy, citrus, nuts, and herbs.
additional_notes: Geosmin drives earthy aroma; sweetness increases with slow roast.
Red varieties add betalain color; golden beets milder, less earthy.
uncertainties: Exact wheel sublabels differ by variety; normalized to red beet archetype.

summary: The floral subgroup (e.g., cauliflower, broccoli rabe’s florets, romanesco) emphasizes green-vegetal notes with sulfur, nutty and roasted aromas when browned. Mild sweetness emerges with gentle cooking; high heat adds toasted notes.
additional_notes: Sulfur compounds (glucosinolates/isothiocyanates) define raw aroma; mellow with heat.
Roasting concentrates sweetness and nutty pyrazines.
uncertainties: Exact sub-variety distinctions not shown; generalized floral-brassica profile.

summary: Leafy brassicas (kale, collards, cabbage leaves) are green and sulfurous raw; cooking softens bitterness and brings nutty/toasty notes. Acid and fat round edges; aromatics and cured meats add savory depth.
additional_notes: Glucosinolates break down to isothiocyanates (pungent); blanching reduces sharpness.
Acidic dressings brighten; toasting and stir-fry add nutty pyrazines.
uncertainties: Relative sizes normalized; specific cultivar variance not depicted.

summary: Citrus fruits combine bright acidity with floral, green, and bitter peel notes (terpenes). Juice adds sharp sourness; zest provides aromatic oils. Sugar balances acid; heat transforms zest into marmalade-like caramel bitterness.
additional_notes: Key volatiles: limonene, linalool, citral; bitter from naringin in some species.
Acid and aromatic intensity vary widely by variety and ripeness.
uncertainties: Exact varietal subdivisions (lemon, lime, orange) not separated; composite citrus profile.

summary: Cocoa/chocolate’s flavor develops through fermentation, roasting, and conching: roasted, nutty, caramel, fruity, floral, earthy, and bitter. Fat carries aromas; dairy softens bitterness; nuts and coffee amplify roasted notes; citrus and berries add lift.
additional_notes: Key compounds include pyrazines, aldehydes, esters; bitterness from theobromine and polyphenols.
Roast level (light→dark) shifts balance between fruity/floral and roasted/bitter.
uncertainties: Exact partitioning varies by roast and origin; sizes normalized to generic dark chocolate.

summary: Lettuces present delicate green, watery sweetness and mild bitterness; some varieties show peppery or nutty notes. They pair with herbs, citrus, dairy, and nuts; bitterness is balanced by acid and fat.
additional_notes: Heat quickly wilts and dulls aromatics; keep cold and dress just before serving.
Varieties differ: romaine (nutty/green), butterhead (sweet/creamy), frisée (bitter).
uncertainties: Matrix varies across varietals; generalized lettuce profile used.

summary: Pomegranate delivers bright tartness with deep red-fruit flavors, floral aromas, and a tannic edge from seeds. Its juice balances savory dishes and enriches desserts; reductions yield molasses-like depth.
additional_notes: Pomegranate molasses concentrates tart-sweet balance with mild bitterness.
Anthocyanins provide color; tannins add astringency.
uncertainties: Exact varietal-specific floral/fruit subdivisions not legible; normalized profile.

summary: Winter squash (butternut, kabocha, acorn) is sweet, earthy, and nutty with caramel potential. Roasting develops toasted and brown-butter notes; herbs and warm spices complement; acids and dairy balance sweetness.
additional_notes: High carotenoids drive color and some flavor; starch converts to sugars during curing.
Purees carry spices well; seeds offer roasted nutty notes.
uncertainties: Relative contributions vary by cultivar and curing; normalized to butternut/kabocha archetype.

summary: Cereal grains (wheat, barley, oats, quinoa, etc.) are mild, sweet-nutty, and bready when cooked; toasting intensifies roasted, popcorn-like pyrazines. Fermentation adds sour and malty notes. Grains readily carry fat, dairy, and spices, and pair with vegetables, mushrooms, and meats.
additional_notes: Toasting and popping amplify nutty/roasty aromas.
Malting develops caramel and malt notes.
Whole grains bring more earthy/bran flavors; refined grains skew neutral.
uncertainties: Wheel sublabels for individual grains not fully legible; values normalized to a generic cooked/toasted grain profile.

summary: Nuts are rich and fatty with sweet, roasted, and woody notes that intensify when toasted. Different nuts vary (almond floral/marzipan, hazelnut cocoa-like, walnut tannic). Salt, caramel, chocolate, coffee, and warm spices complement; acids and fruits add lift.
additional_notes: Toasting develops pyrazines that read as roasted and popcorn-like.
Walnut and pecan show more tannin/bitterness; pistachio is greener and more floral.
uncertainties: Wheel includes many individual nuts; this entry summarizes across common types.

summary: Corn is sweet and green when fresh; cooking builds buttery, creamy, and roasted popcorn-like notes. Dry corn (polenta, masa) leans toasty and nutty; nixtamalization adds lime/alkaline complexity. Corn pairs with dairy, herbs, chiles, pork, and smoky flavors.
additional_notes: Fresh kernels emphasize green and fruity esters; dry-milled corn emphasizes roasted pyrazines.
Popcorn releases distinct toasty aromatics.
uncertainties: Wheel shows many fruit/spice sublabels; not all are legible at this resolution.

summary: Capsicum (sweet and hot peppers) spans green, fruity, and floral notes; roasting adds smoky-roasted depth. Heat (from capsaicin) delivers pungency that pairs with dairy, citrus, herbs, and sweet elements. Dried chiles show raisin, cocoa, and tobacco notes.
additional_notes: Green bell has grassy/methoxypyrazine notes; ripening increases fruitiness.
Capsaicin is fat-soluble; dairy mitigates heat.
Roasting/peeling introduces smoky/charred notes.
uncertainties: Exact fruit family subdivisions on wheel are too small to read; values normalized.

summary: Berries (strawberry, raspberry, blueberry, blackberry, cranberry) are intensely fruity with floral top notes and varying acidity. They pair with cream, vanilla, citrus, cocoa, and herbs; savory uses include with game meats and vinegar reductions.
additional_notes: Ester- and terpene-rich aromatics vary by species; anthocyanins deliver color.
Acidity ranges from very high (cranberry) to moderate (blueberry).
uncertainties: Individual berry labels on wheel (e.g., strawberry, blueberry) are present but not fully legible.

summary: Rice ranges from neutral and sweet-starchy (white) to nutty, popcorn-like (toasted, basmati), to earthy (brown/black). It is an excellent flavor carrier for fat, stock, and spices; toasting (pilaf) and frying deepen roasty notes.
additional_notes: Basmati has 2-acetyl-1-pyrroline (popcorn-like); sticky rice is neutral and sweet.
Toasting/poaching methods (pilaf/risotto) change aroma balance.
uncertainties: Outer ring items for specific rice varieties/spices are not fully legible; sizes normalized.

summary: Tomatoes balance sweet, sour, and green-herbal notes with umami from glutamates. Ripeness increases fruity and floral facets; cooking concentrates sweetness and adds roasted depth. They pair with herbs, dairy, alliums, olive oil, and meats.
additional_notes: Key volatiles include cis-3-hexenal (green) and various esters/terpenes.
Slow roasting and reduction deepen caramel and savory notes.
uncertainties: Wheel includes many specific herb/spice nodes; relative sizes normalized by visual proportion.

summary: Crustaceans (shrimp, crab, lobster) have sweet, briny, and savory flavors that intensify with browning. Butter, citrus, herbs, garlic, and chili are classic complements; shell toasting yields deep roasted/umami notes used in stocks and sauces.
additional_notes: Shells contain chitin and free amino acids; roasting shells produces strong Maillard/umami aromas.
Delicate meat overcooks easily; quick high heat or gentle poach preferred.
uncertainties: Outer ring spice/herb details too small to read; normalized contributions reported.

summary: Carrots are sweet, earthy, and green with citrusy and floral terpenes (e.g., β-ionone). Roasting and glazing enhance caramel and nutty notes; fresh or pickled forms emphasize green and acidic facets. Pair with butter, citrus, herbs, warm spices, and nuts.
additional_notes: Younger carrots are greener and less earthy; purple varieties add tannic/phenolic notes.
Glazing concentrates sugars; roasting builds deep browned flavors.
uncertainties: Many spice and herb sublabels exist on the wheel; exact percentages are estimated by visual proportion.

summary: Cucumber is crisp, watery, and intensely green with melon-like and floral nuances. Bitterness can appear near skin/seeds. Acid, salt, herbs, and dairy (yogurt) enhance freshness; heat usually dulls aromatics, so use raw or lightly pickled.
additional_notes: Green notes driven by C6 aldehydes (hexenal/hexenol).
Salt and acid increase perceived sweetness and reduce bitterness.
uncertainties: Outer ring fruit/herb items are numerous; exact labels unreadable at this resolution.

summary: Game meats (venison, elk, wild boar, etc.) are robust, iron-rich, and slightly barnyardy with earthy and woody nuances. Dry aging and browning intensify savory, roasted, and nutty notes. Classic partners are resinous herbs, berries, red wine, mushrooms, cocoa, and smoke.
additional_notes: Lean musculature benefits from added fat (barding) or moist methods.
Marinades with alcohol/fruit soften metallic notes.
Smoke and char complement gamy aromatics.
uncertainties: Outer-ring spice sublabels on the wheel are too small to read precisely at this resolution; strengths normalized by visual proportion.

summary: Truffles are intensely earthy, musky, and garlicky with savory sulfur notes. They perfume fats and eggs and pair naturally with mushrooms, potatoes, pasta, dairy, and poultry. Gentle heat and fat capture aromatics; long cooking can diminish them.
additional_notes: Shave raw or finish at low heat to preserve volatiles.
Black truffle skews cocoa/earthy; white truffle is sharper/garlicky.
uncertainties: Exact fruit nodes on wheel are illegible; this captures the dominant families visible.

summary: Pork is sweet, fatty, and savory with a mild meaty profile that loves browning, smoke, and spices. Classic partners include apple, mustard, garlic, sage, fennel, chilies, and sweet elements like maple. Cured pork shows nutty, smoky, and spiced notes.
additional_notes: Belly/shoulder carry spice and sweetness well; lean cuts need fat and salt.
Smoke and fermentation (cured meats) add complexity.
uncertainties: Wheel shows many nut types and sweets on outer ring; exact labels not fully readable.

summary: Melons (cantaloupe, honeydew, watermelon) are sweet, watery, and green-floral with cucumber-like freshness. Acid and salt heighten flavor; salty cured meats, chili, herbs, and citrus are classic contrasts.
additional_notes: Aldehydes drive green freshness; ripeness raises ester/floral notes.
Keep cold and add acid/salt to sharpen.
uncertainties: Individual fruit subnodes (banana, lychee, etc.) on wheel are visible but not legible; normalized sizes used.

summary: Stone fruits (peach, nectarine, apricot, cherry, plum) are lush and floral with almond-like kernels. Cooking concentrates sweetness and adds caramel/roasted notes. They love vanilla, almond, dairy, spices, smoke, and rich meats like pork and duck.
additional_notes: Benzaldehyde from kernels reads as almond/marzipan.
Sour varieties (plum, apricot) balance fattier meats well.
uncertainties: Outer ring labels for specific spirits and nuts are not legible; normalized values shown.

summary: Brassica rapa family (turnip, napa cabbage, bok choy, mizuna, tatsoi) shows mustardy, peppery pungency with green and earthy sweetness. Quick cooking or pickling tames sharpness; sesame, soy, ginger, garlic, and vinegar suit the profile.
additional_notes: Isothiocyanates drive pungency; sweetness increases with roasting.
Leaves are milder than roots.
uncertainties: Wheel’s outer spice/herb sticks are many; exact names unreadable at this zoom.

summary: Radishes are crisp and watery with sharp mustardy heat and a faint earthy sweetness. They shine raw with salt, butter, acid, and herbs; roasting mellows heat and raises sweetness.
additional_notes: Isothiocyanates give peppery bite; leaves are more herbal and can be sautéed.
Ice water crisps texture.
uncertainties: Individual outer nodes (tea, wine, etc.) not fully legible at this size.

summary: Fish ranges from delicate and sweet to rich and meaty; common traits are marine/briny freshness and high umami. Gentle heat, browning, or smoking add complexity. Classic partners are lemon, herbs, garlic, soy, miso, butter, and olive oil.
additional_notes: Fatty fish handle smoke and bold sauces; lean fish prefer moist cooking.
Shell/skin roasting contributes deep Maillard flavors.
uncertainties: The wheel shows specific fish types and many spices; labels are too small to capture exactly.

summary: Eggplant is mild and vegetal with slight bitterness in skin and seeds. Roasting or frying brings out meaty, smoky, and sweet notes. It pairs with tomato, garlic, onion, sesame/tahini, miso, basil, oregano, and warm spices.
additional_notes: Salting draws moisture and moderates bitterness.
High heat roasting/char adds smoke and meaty texture.
uncertainties: Many outer labels (specific spices and nuts) are unreadable; proportions estimated from the visible wedges.

summary: Tropical fruits (mango, pineapple, banana, papaya, coconut, passion fruit, etc.) are intensely fruity and floral with varying acidity and sometimes creamy/fatty notes (coconut). They pair with lime, chili, ginger, mint, rum, vanilla, and dairy.
additional_notes: Pineapple’s bromelain tenderizes meat; papaya contains papain.
Coconut contributes fat that carries volatile esters.
uncertainties: The wheel shows many individual fruits on the outer ring; this collapses them into a single tropical family with normalized weights.

Green Bean.summary: No narrative paragraph is visible on the provided page image; the page shows a flavor wheel with green-bean photo.
additional_notes: Wheel shows inner families: Herbaceous, Green, Fruit-like, Earthy, Savory, Sour, Marine, Wood, Spice, Terpene, Medicinal, Toasted, Roasted, Nutty, Meaty, Chocolate, Caramel, Pungent, Phenol, Tropical, Tree fruit, Berry, Citrus, Dairy, Alcohol.
An outer percentage guide ring appears with ticks up to 100.
uncertainties: Many outer-ring ingredient labels are too small to confirm; above lists only those readable at this resolution.
Relative-size and thickness values are approximate visual estimates from the photo, not measured from source artwork.

Root Vegetable.summary: Photo shows assorted root vegetables and a flavor wheel. No paragraph text is visible.
additional_notes: Inner families identical to other pages in the book (Herbaceous through Citrus, Dairy, Alcohol).

matrix_nodes.label: Earthy
matrix_nodes.notes: earthy wedge appears large on root-vegetable page

matrix_nodes.label: Spice
matrix_nodes.notes: long list of baking spices readable on outer ring

uncertainties: Specific outer labels in fruit zones not reliably readable from the image.

Kiwi.summary: Photo of sliced kiwi with standard flavor wheel; no paragraph visible.
additional_notes: Tropical and tree-fruit segments look comparatively large for this page.

matrix_edges.notes: outermost long bar labeled 'tea' is clearly visible on this page

uncertainties: Only a subset of outer-ring fruit labels are readable at this resolution.

Ginger.summary: Page shows fresh ginger and a flavor wheel. No visible narrative paragraph.
additional_notes: Wheel emphasizes Spice and Pungent sectors for ginger; bars for ginger-adjacent spices appear long.

matrix_nodes.label: All other families
matrix_nodes.notes: remainder across Herbaceous, Fruit-like, Savory, etc.

uncertainties: Outer labels inside fruit zones are too small to confirm exhaustively.

Olive.summary: Page shows assorted olives with the flavor wheel. No paragraph visible.

matrix_edges.notes: self-referential outer label present next to red wine/tea cluster

uncertainties: Exact bar lengths are visually estimated.

Jerusalem Artichoke.summary: Sunchokes shown with the flavor wheel; no narrative text visible.
uncertainties: Other outer labels present but not fully legible at this resolution.

Grape.summary: Assorted grapes with a flavor wheel; no paragraph blocks visible.
uncertainties: Specific fruit names inside berry/tree-fruit arcs are largely illegible in the photo.

Lamb.summary: Cuts of lamb next to a flavor wheel; no prose paragraphs visible.
additional_notes: Spice and Herbaceous/Green sections include classic lamb herbs (but individual herb labels are too small to verify exhaustively).
uncertainties: Many outer labels are small; only clearly readable ones listed.

Asparagus.summary: Photo of green and white asparagus spears with a flavor wheel.

matrix_nodes.label: Phenol/Pungent
matrix_nodes.notes: cluster with brassica/mustard/radish; large 'tea' bar also present

matrix_edges.notes: very long bar on this page

uncertainties: Additional small labels present across fruit zones but not confidently legible.

Cress.summary: Cress leaves with a flavor wheel; no paragraph blocks present in the photo.
uncertainties: Smaller outer labels in fruit and spice areas not reliably readable at this size.

Green Bean (extra readable outer labels).summary: Supplemental list of clearly readable outer-ring items unique to the Green Bean wheel image.

uncertainties: This supplemental section exists because those two labels were distinctly readable; most others overlap with the generic set above.

Global wheel patterns (applies to all pa.summary: The book’s wheels share a consistent structure; where a label appears across several pages, I’ve listed it once above when clearly legible on at least one of the ten images.
additional_notes: Consistent readable outer-ring items across many pages: tea, red wine, olive (phenolic cluster); brassica, mustard, radish (pungent cluster); meats (beef, chicken, lamb, pork, turkey); nuts (almond, peanut, hazelnut, walnut, pecan, pistachio); toasted/roasted set (brown butter, coffee, baked bread, rye bread, popcorn); common warm spices (cinnamon, clove, nutmeg, ginger, cardamom, star anise).
uncertainties: Exact quantitative bar lengths require vector artwork or higher-resolution scans; current estimates are visual.

summary: Avocado is rich, green, and nutty with buttery texture from high oleic fat. Mild bitterness is masked by acid and salt; heat brings toasted and nutty notes while raw use preserves herbal freshness.
additional_notes: Oxidizes quickly; acid and oil slow browning.
Best raw or lightly charred; heat too long can turn grassy flavors bitter.
Seasonality: year-round from multiple regions.
uncertainties: Wheel percentages estimated by proportion; exact text partially unreadable.

summary: Potato is earthy, starchy, and mildly sweet; cooking unlocks roasted, nutty, and toasted aromas via Maillard reactions. Different varieties skew buttery, nutty, or mineral.
additional_notes: Starch retrogradation firms when cool; mash hot and serve warm.
Brown butter, roasting, and frying amplify nutty/toasty notes.
Store cool and dark to avoid greening/solanine.
uncertainties: Exact wheel breakdown estimated by image.

summary: Summer squash is delicate, green, and watery-sweet with faint seed and melon notes. High heat creates nutty, toasted flavors; gentle cooking preserves freshness.
additional_notes: Salt early to purge moisture before sautéing or grilling.
Raw ribbons work with citrus and salty cheese.
Flowers are floral-sweet and pair with fresh cheeses.
uncertainties: Minor sublabels unreadable; proportions estimated.

summary: Fig is jammy-sweet with honey, caramel, and dried fruit notes; green figs carry a fresh, sappy edge while dried figs skew molasses and nutty.
additional_notes: Roasting concentrates caramel and toasted notes.
Acid (balsamic/citrus) balances intense sweetness.
Seasonality: late summer to early fall.
uncertainties: Exact wheel segment names approximated from legibility.

summary: Honey ranges from floral and fruity to malty, woody, and caramelized depending on variety and processing. Heat darkens and adds toffee/butterscotch; acidity and salt moderate sweetness.
additional_notes: Raw honey preserves floral volatiles; heating drives caramel notes.
Water activity is low; antimicrobial in certain contexts.
Varietal differences are significant (e.g., buckwheat vs. acacia).
uncertainties: Wheel subtypes vary by varietal; generalized here.

summary: Chicken is mild and meaty with fatty, roasted, and caramel notes depending on cut and cooking; skin and browning add toasted and nutty depth.
additional_notes: Brining increases juiciness; dry-brine for crisp skin.
Dark meat has higher myoglobin and deeper flavor.
Maillard at high heat drives roasted/nutty notes.
uncertainties: Wheel proportions estimated from image.

summary: Caramel is dominated by caramelized sugar notes—butterscotch, toffee, and browned butter—plus nutty, roasted, and malty tones. Salt enhances complexity and suppresses bitterness.
additional_notes: Higher temps yield darker, more bitter caramel.
Water/cream additions control texture from sauce to brittle.
Salted caramel amplifies aroma and balances sweetness.
uncertainties: Wheel details inferred from visible labels and category knowledge.

summary: Mushrooms are earthy, savory, and woody with umami and subtle nutty/roasted aromas; species vary from mild button to meaty maitake and king trumpet.
additional_notes: Searing evaporates moisture for browning; avoid crowding pan.
Glutamates/5′-ribonucleotides synergize with kombu, miso, and parmesan.
Drying intensifies woodsy and nutty notes.
uncertainties: Mixed species wheel aggregated qualitatively.

summary: Fennel is sweet, green, and anise-like; raw it is crisp and herbal, while roasting brings caramel, nutty, and toasted notes that pair with citrus and seafood.
additional_notes: Fronds are intensely herbal; use as an herb.
High heat caramelizes sugars; braising mellows anise.
Pairs well with licorice/anise spirits and citrus.
uncertainties: Exact percentages inferred from wheel proportions.

summary: Apple ranges from green/tart to honeyed and floral with spicy, woody notes when baked. Acidity brightens savory dishes; browning adds caramel and toasted aromas.
additional_notes: Acid and pectin structure vary strongly by variety.
Baking concentrates sugar and caramel flavors.
Oxidation causes browning; acid reduces it.
uncertainties: Wheel labels partly obscured; values normalized by visual estimate.

summary: Eggs are neutral-savory with sulfurous notes from cysteine and methionine, rich fat from yolk, and gentle dairy-like sweetness. Heat transforms texture and Maillard aromas; emulsifies and binds. Acid and herbs brighten; smoke and browned butter add depth.
additional_notes: Yolk lecithin gives strong emulsifying power (mayonnaise, hollandaise).
Gentle heat (63–65 °C) yields custardy yolks; high heat increases sulfur.
Freshness matters: older whites thin and foam more easily.
Salt early for tender curds in scrambles; acid reduces sulfur perception.

matrix_nodes.label: Savory
matrix_nodes.notes: Umami from nucleotides; enhanced by MSG/soy

matrix_nodes.label: Roasted
matrix_nodes.notes: Browning at pan edges, baked custards

uncertainties: Exact wheel segment percentages unreadable; sizes normalized by visual estimation.

summary: Vinegar contributes bright acetic acidity with fermentation complexity (esters, aldehydes). Styles vary: rice (soft), cider (fruity), balsamic (caramelized, woody). It sharpens flavors, balances fat, and heightens sweetness while suppressing bitterness.
additional_notes: Use small amounts to brighten without sourness; salt synergizes.
Reduce balsamic for syrupy caramel and dried-fruit notes.
Acid retards Maillard; add near the end when browning is desired.
De-glaze pans to capture fond; balance with fat/sugar.
uncertainties: Wheel shows multiple styles; values reflect an average profile.

summary: Alliums range from sweet to pungent via sulfur compounds (thiols, thiosulfinates). Heat mellows sharpness and brings caramelized sweetness; raw forms add bite and freshness. Acid/salt temper burn; fat captures sweet-savory aromas.
additional_notes: Slice direction changes texture; soak raw slices in ice water to soften heat.
Long, slow cooking builds jammy umami; add a pinch of baking soda to speed browning.
Use acid (vinegar, lemon) to brighten and reduce pungency.
Store cool and dry; do not refrigerate whole onions.
uncertainties: Wheel aggregates several alliums; values reflect blended profile.

summary: Peas are green and sweet with fresh grassy pyrazines, a light starchiness, and delicate floral fruitiness. Quick cooking preserves chlorophyll and crispness; mint and dairy accent sweetness; acidity keeps flavors vivid.
additional_notes: Blanch briefly and shock to lock color; overcooking dulls and sulfury notes emerge.
Purées benefit from a little sugar and acid to boost perceived freshness.
Mint and lemon amplify green sweetness through shared terpenes.
Choose just-ripe peas for highest sugar content.
uncertainties: Exact percentages estimated from wheel proportions.

summary: Oysters/clams/scallops offer briny sweetness and minerality; octopus adds meaty, slightly earthy notes. Gentle heat keeps sweetness; high heat browns surfaces for nutty, caramelized depth. Acid and herbs brighten; butter amplifies savoriness.
additional_notes: Salinity varies by habitat; purge or rinse as needed.
Sear dry scallops in very hot fat for crust; avoid overcooking to keep tenderness.
Octopus benefits from slow tenderizing before charring.
Iodine/mineral notes love acid and anise herbs (fennel, tarragon).
uncertainties: Wheel includes multiple species; values are averaged.

summary: Fresh dairy provides creamy fat, delicate sweetness, and cultured tang (yogurt, crème fraîche). It softens heat, rounds bitterness, and carries volatile aromas. Browning (baked milk solids) adds nutty, toffee notes.
additional_notes: Acid will curdle milk—temper or stabilize with starch/sugar.
Brown butter develops hazelnut-like notes (diacetyl, lactones).
Cultured dairy adds lactic tang and thicker body (exopolysaccharides).
Fat enhances aroma delivery; salt heightens sweetness.
uncertainties: Wheel spans multiple dairy forms; sizes reflect composite profile.

summary: Lemongrass is bright-citral, lemony, and green with woody fiber. Bruising or slicing releases oils; simmering infuses broths. Combines with ginger, coconut, chili, and fish sauce in Southeast Asian profiles; sugar and fat round sharp edges.
additional_notes: Use tender inner stalk; reserve outer leaves for infusions.
Citral degrades with long high heat—add part near the end for freshness.
Pairs with aromatics in curry pastes; sugar balances bitterness.
Char/grill for smoky-citrus complexity.
uncertainties: Segment sizes read approximately from the wheel.

summary: Vanilla is warm, sweet, and creamy from vanillin, with phenolic, woody, and floral undertones. Alcohol extracts amplify diffusion; fat carries flavor. Caramel and chocolate resonate; tropical fruits and stone fruits create layered desserts.
additional_notes: Scrape seeds and steep pods; reuse pods to make vanilla sugar/extract.
Heat intensifies aroma but can volatilize—add some at finish.
Smoky, woody notes pair with bourbon/rum and toasted nuts.
Works in savory contexts to amplify sweetness and round acidity.
uncertainties: Wheel bars approximated from image scale.
